Help.#cdata: Produces a compact, minimal HTML that does not use style information.

Produces output that contains columns of data values that are separated by commas. ODS CSVALL 
produces tabular output with titles, notes, and bylines.
Aligns values by the decimal point in numeric columns when no justification is specified.
Creates an ODS document.
Defines a representative character to be used in output strings.
Specifies output objects to exclude from ODS destinations.
Opens, manages, or closes the HTML3 destination, which produces HTML 3.2 formatted output.
Produces HTML that is similar to ODS HTML with cascading style sheets.
Opens, manages, or closes the HTML destination, which produces HTML 4.0 embedded stylesheets.
Produces HTML that is a column of output, separated by lines.
Opens, manages, or closes the LISTING destination.
Opens, manages, or closes one or more specified destinations.

Creates a SAS data set from an output object and manages the selection and exclusion lists for the 
Output destination.
Provides portable support for PCL (HP LaserJet) files.
Opens, manages, or closes the PDF destination.
Produces a basic HTML that uses twelve style elements and no class attributes.
Opens, manages, or closes the PRINTER destination.
Enables you to change a procedure label.

Determines whether to suppress the writing of the title that identifies the procedure that produces 
the results.
Opens, manages, or closes the PostScript destination.
Tracks ODS output in the Results window.
Creates SAS output in Rich Text Format for Microsoft Word
Specifies output objects to send to the ODS destinations.
Writes the specified selection or exclusion list to the SAS log.

Writes to the SAS log a record of each output object that is created, or suppresses the writing 
of this record.

Writes or suppresses a warning that a style definition or a table definition that is used is not 
supplied by SAS.

Uses the Wireless Application Protocol (WAP) to produce a Wireless Markup Language (WML) DTD with 
a simple href list for a table of contents.
Closes the destination and any files that are associated with it.

ToolTips.@ToolTip1: Produces compact, minimal HTML output that does not use style information.
ToolTips.@ToolTip2: Contains a table of Unicode values and mnemonics.
ToolTips.@ToolTip3: Produces tabular output that contains  columns of data values that are separated by commas.
ToolTips.@ToolTip4: Produces tabular output with titles that contain columns of data values that are separated by commas.
ToolTips.@ToolTip5: Produces output with comma-separated values and columns of data that are separated by commas.
ToolTips.@ToolTip7: Produces XML output that conforms to the DocBook DTD by OASIS.
ToolTips.@ToolTip8: Produces Microsoft's spreadsheetML XML. This tagset is used to import data into XML.
ToolTips.@ToolTip10: produces HTML output with cascading style sheets that is similar to ODS HTML output.
ToolTips.@ToolTip12: produces HTML output as a column of output that is separated by lines.
ToolTips.@ToolTip13: Produces HTML code for output generated by ODS for Microsoft Office products.
ToolTips.@ToolTip14: Produces URLs within HTML files that are used in the z/OS operating environment.
ToolTips.@ToolTip15: Produces simple HTML output that uses twelve style elements and no class attributes.
ToolTips.@ToolTip16: Produces PYX, which is a simple, line-oriented notation used by Pyxie to describe the information  communicated by an XML parser to an XML application.
ToolTips.@ToolTip18: Causes imbedded data to be produced in CSV format.
ToolTips.@ToolTip19: Uses the Wireless Application Protocol (WAP) to produce a Wireless Markup Language (WML) DTD with  a list of URLs as a table of contents.
ToolTips.@ToolTip20: Uses the Wireless Application Protocol (WAP) to produce a Wireless Markup Language (WML) DTD with  an option list for the table of contents.
ToolTips.@ToolTip22: Creates XML output that shows which events are being triggered and which variables are used by an  event to send output from a SAS process to an output file.
ToolTips.@ToolTip23: Creates HTML output similar to STYLE_POPUP, but with all the objects labeled as they are when  using ODS TRACE.
ToolTips.@ToolTip24: Creates a subset of the XML output that is created by the EVENT_MAP tagset.
ToolTips.@ToolTip25: Creates a sample page of HTML output that is similar to STYLE_POPUP output.
ToolTips.@ToolTip26: Creates HTML like HTMLCSS, but if you're using Internet Explorer, STYLE_POPUP displays a window  that shows the resolved ODS style definition for any item that you select.
ToolTips.@ToolTip27: Creates text output that shows which events are being triggered as ODS handles the output objects.
ToolTips.@ToolTip28: Creates HTML output in a bulleted list similar to EVENT_MAP but lists only a subset of the  possible attributes.
ToolTips.@ToolTip29: Creates XML output similar to EVENT_MAP but lists only a subset of the possible attributes.

Help.#cdata:
Specifies a keyword value for a tagset. A tagset is a template that defines how to create an output 
type from a SAS format.

[Syntax: ANCHOR='anchor-name'] 
    
Specifies a unique base name for the anchor tag that identifies each output 
object in the current body file.

[Syntax: AUTHOR='author-text'] 
     
Inserts the text string that you specify as the author into the metadata 
of a file.

[Syntax: ARCHIVE='string'] 
    
The ARCHIVE= option is only valid for the GOPTIONS Java device. The ARCHIVE= option 
allows you to specify a string to identify which applet to use in order to view the 
ODS HTML output.

[Syntax: ATTRIBUTES=(attribute-pair-1 ... attribute-pair-n)] 
     
Writes the specified attributes between the tags that generate dynamic graphics output.

[Syntax: BASE= 'base-text'] 
    
Specifies the text to use as the first part of all links and references that ODS 
creates in the output files.

[Syntax: BODY= 'file-specification' <sub-option(s)>] 
    
Opens a MARKUP family destination and specifies the file that contains the 
primary output that is created by the ODS statement.

[Syntax: CHARSET=character-set] 
    
Specifies the character set to be generated in the META declaration for the HTML output.

[Syntax: CODE= 'file-specification' <sub-option(s)>] 
    
Opens a MARKUP family destination and specifies the file that contains relevant 
style information, such as XSL (Extensible Stylesheet Language).

[Syntax: CODEBASE='string'] 
    
Creates a file path that is used by the GOPTIONS devices.
Generates a printable table of contents page.
Does not generate a printable table of contents.

Specifies that SAS titles and footnotes are placed into the body of the document instead of into the 
headers and footers section of the document.

Specifies that SAS titles and footnotes are placed into the body of the document instead of into the 
headers and footers section of the document.

[Syntax: CONTENTS= 'file-specification' <sub-option(s)>] 
    
Opens a MARKUP family destination and specifies the file that contains 
a table of contents for the output.

ToolTips.@ToolTip1: n is the number of page columns. Replace it with an integer value.
ToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies the maximum number of 1-inch-wide columns for this paper size and margin setting.  This value is dependent upon the paper size and page orientation. The maximum number is 8.

Help.#cdata: Specifies the number of columns to place across each page of output.

[Syntax: ENCODING='encoding-value'] 
    
Specifies the encoding to use when SAS is reading from or writing to an external file.

Syntax: EVENT=event-name (FILE= | FINISH | LABEL= | NAME= | START | STYLE= |TARGET= | TEXT= | URL= )
    
Specifies an event and the value for event variables that are associated with the event.

Syntax: CSSSTYLE='file-specification'<(media-type-1 <...media-type-10>)> 
    
Specifies a cascading style sheet to apply to your output.
Specifies an output file destination.
Specifies the image resolution for output files. Default: 150
Inserts into the output file's metadata, a string of keywords.
Specifies that ODS use the printer drivers that the host system provides.
Triggers the finish section of an event.

[Syntax: LABEL='variable-value'] 
    
Specifies the value for the LABEL event variable.

[Syntax: NAME='variable-value'] 
    
Specifies the value for the NAME event variable.
Triggers the start section of an event.
Writes the time and the date that you started your SAS session.
Specifies a style element or style definition.

ToolTips.@ToolTip1: Inserts a new page at the start of each procedure and within certain procedures, as is requested by  the procedure code.
ToolTips.@ToolTip2: Instructs ODS not to insert any new pages at the start of each procedure or within certain procedures,  even if the procedure code requests new pages.
ToolTips.@ToolTip3: Forces the immediate insertion of a new page.
ToolTips.@ToolTip4: Specifies not to insert page breaks, even before graphics procedures.

Help.#cdata: Controls page breaks.

[Syntax: TARGET='variable-value'] 
    
Specifies the value for the TARGET event variable.

[Syntax: TEXT='variable-value'] 
    
Specifies the value for the TEXT event variable.
Specifies a URL address variable.

Syntax: FRAME='file-specification' <sub-option(s)> 
    
Opens a MARKUP family destination and, for HTML output, specifies the file that integrates the table 
of contents, the page contents, and the body file.
Prints footnotes that are created by SAS/GRAPH, which appear inside the graph borders.
Prints footnotes that are created by ODS, which will appear outside the graph borders.
ODS allows table splits only if the entire table cannot fit on one page.
ODS lets a table split at a page break.
Instructs ODS not to insert contents data into the RTF file.
Instructs ODS to insert contents data into the RTF file.
Specifies the image resolution for graphical output. Default: 100

Syntax: GPATH= file-specification <(url='Uniform-Resource-Locator' | NONE)> 
   
Specifies the location for all graphics output that is generated while the destination is open.

Prints the title that is created by SAS/GRAPH, the SGPLOT procedure, the SGPANEL procedure, or the 
SGSCATTER procedure. The title appears inside the graph borders.
Prints the title that is created by ODS, which will appear outside the graph borders.
Specifies tags to place between the <HEAD> and </HEAD> tags in all the files that the destination writes to.

[Syntax: (ID=identifier)] 
   
Enables you to run multiple instances of the same destination at the same time. Each 
instance can have different options.

[Syntax: FONTSCALE=percent] 
    
Specifies a scaling factor to apply to all of the font sizes that do not have 
an explicit unit of measure.

Specifies HTML code to use as the <META> tag between the <HEAD> and </HEAD> tags of all 
the HTML files that the destination writes to.

ToolTips.@ToolTip1: Starts a new file for the results of each BY group.
ToolTips.@ToolTip2: Writes all output to the body file that is currently open.
ToolTips.@ToolTip3: Starts a new body file for each output object.
ToolTips.@ToolTip4: Starts a new body file for each page of output.
ToolTips.@ToolTip5: Starts a new body file each time that you start a new procedure.

Help.#cdata:
Syntax: NEWFILE=BYGROUP|NONE|OUTPUT|PAGE|PROC] 
    
Creates a new body file at the specified starting-point.

Opens a destination and specifies the file that contains a description of each page of the body 
file, and contains links to the body file.

[Syntax: PARAMETERS=(parameter-pair-1 ... parameter-pair-n)] 
    
Writes the specified parameters between the tags that generate dynamic graphics output.

Syntax: PATH= file-specification (URL= 'Uniform-Resource-Locator' | NONE) 
   
Specifies the location of an external file or a SAS catalog for all markup files.
[Syntax: ] Inserts the text you specify into the metadata section of the file.

Syntax: RECORD_SEPARATOR= 'alternative-separator' | NONE 
    
Specifies an alternative character or string that separates lines in the output files.

Syntax: STYLESHEET= 'file-specification' <sub-option(s)> 
    
Opens a destination and places the style information for output into an external file, or reads 
stylesheet information from an existing file.
Produces output with comma-separated values and columns of data that are separated by commas.
Produces tabular output that contains columns of data values that are separated by commas.
Produces XML output.

Opens, manages, or closes the DOCBOOK destination, which produces XML output that conforms to the 
DocBook DTD by OASIS.

Creates XML output that shows which events are being triggered and which variables are used by an 
event to send output from a SAS process to an output file.
Produces HTML 4.0 embedded stylesheets.
Produces LaTeX, which is a document preparation system for high-quality typesetting.
Produces HTML code for output generated by ODS for Microsoft Office products.
Produces URLs within HTML files that are used in the z/OS operating environment.
Creates PROC TEMPLATE code for the STYLESHEET= option.
Creates PROC TEMPLATE code for the STYLESHEET= option.
Produces an ODS XML remote program command stream.

Produces PYX, which is a simple, line-oriented notation used by Pyxie to describe the information 
communicated by an XML parser to an XML application. Pyxie is an Open Source library for processing 
XML with the Python programming language.
Produces format markup tags that you create for the XML engine.
Produces alternate missing-value markup tags for the XML engine.
Produces alternate "no space in text" value markup for the XML engine.
Produce generic XML code that is similar to the Oracle8iXML implementation used by ORACLE.
Produces very simple HTML output.

Produces XML code that is supported by the Open Information Model (Database Schema Model) proposed 
by the Metadata Coalition (MDC) as vendor- and technology-independent, conforming to the XML 1.0 
specification.
Produces XML that is equivalent to the Oracle8iXML implementation, which is used by ORACLE.
Creates a subset of the XML output that is created by the EVENT_MAP tagset.
Produces markup for statistical graphs that are generated by SAS procedures.

Creates a sample page of HTML output that is similar to STYLE_POPUP output. The output helps you to 
create and modify styles.

Creates HTML like HTMLCSS, but if you're using Internet Explorer, STYLE_POPUP displays a window that 
shows the resolved ODS style definition for any item that you select.
Creates text output that shows which events are being triggered as ODS handles the output objects.

Creates HTML output in a bulleted list similar to EVENT_MAP but lists only a subset of the 
possible attributes.

Produces Troff code, which is a text-formatting language used for high-quality photo typesetters 
and laser printers.

Uses the Wireless Application Protocol (WAP) to produce a Wireless Markup Language (WML) DTD with an 
option list for the table of contents. For more information, see Wireless Application Protocol.
Specifies the translation table to use when transcoding a file for output.
Specifies that no ending markup language source code be added to the output file
Specifies that no beginning markup language source code be added to the top of the output file.

Inserts into the metadata of a file, the text string that you specify as the text to appear in the 
title bar of the browser window.
Enables you to send output directly to a web server instead of writing it to a file.

Enables or disables ODS graphics processing and sets graphics environment options. This statement 
affects ODS template-based graphics only.
Disables an option or statement.
Enables ODS Graphics processing. This is the default if no argument is used.
Smooths jagged edges of all components in the graph.
Does not smooth jagged edges of components other than text in the graph.

ToolTips.@ToolTip1: Does not smooth jagged edges of components other than text in the graph.
ToolTips.@ToolTip2: Smooths jagged edges of all components in the graph.

Help.#cdata: Specifies whether anti-aliasing is applied to the rendering of the line and markers in any graph.

Specifies the maximum number of markers or lines to be anti-aliased before anti-aliasing is disabled. 
Default: 1000
Specifies to draw a border around the graph.
Specifies not to draw a border around the graph.

ToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies not to draw a border around the graph.
ToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies to draw a border around the graph.

Help.#cdata: Specifies whether to draw a border around the graph.
Specifies the maximum number of discrete values to be shown in any graph. Default: 1000

ToolTips.@ToolTip1: Writes the specified number of observations in a panel, if possible. More than one panel can occur on  every page if space permits.   Range: 1 to the largest integer that the operating system supports.
ToolTips.@ToolTip2: Bases the size of the panel on the way that the table is stored in memory. This value provides the  fastest performance. However, if the table contains many columns, the number of rows in each panel  might be small.
ToolTips.@ToolTip3: Tries to make panels that match the page size. If the table contains more columns than can fit on a  page, the first page is filled with as many observations as possible for as many columns as can fit  on a single line. The second page contains the same observations for the next group of columns, and  so on, until all rows and columns have been printed.

Help.#cdata:
Suggests how to split a table that is too wide to fit on a single page into sections of columns and rows. 
Each section of columns and rows is a data panel. Each data panel has column headings at the top.

Specifies the name of a device driver. ODS automatically selects an optimal default device for each 
open output destination.

Specifies the maximum number of group values to be shown in any graph. Any graph that supports the 
GROUP= option is affected. Default: 1000
Specifies the height of any graph.

ToolTips.@ToolTip15: Uses the best quality static image format for the active output destination. This is the default.

Help.#cdata:
[Syntax: IMAGEFMT=image-file-type | STATIC] 
    
Specifies the image format to be used. If the image format is not valid for the active 
output destination, the format is automatically changed to the 
default image format for that destination.
Specifies to generate data tips.
Specifies not to generate data tips.

ToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies not to generate data tips.

Help.#cdata: Specifies to generate data tips.
Specifies the base image filename.
Specifies the maximum number of labeled areas before labeling is disabled. Default: 200

Specifies an integer that is interpreted as the maximum percentage of the overall graphics area that 
a legend can occupy. Default: 20

Specifies the maximum number of cells in a graph panel where the number of cells is determined 
dynamically by classification variables. Default: 10000
Resets all of the options to their defaults.

ToolTips.@ToolTip1: Resets all of the reset-options to their defaults.
ToolTips.@ToolTip2: Resets the ANTIALIAS option to its default.
ToolTips.@ToolTip3: Resets the ANTIALIASMAX option to its default.
ToolTips.@ToolTip4: Resets the BORDER= option to its default.
ToolTips.@ToolTip5: Resets the index counter that is appended to static image files.
ToolTips.@ToolTip6: Resets the HEIGHT= option to its default.
ToolTips.@ToolTip7: Resets the IMAGEMAP= option to its default.
ToolTips.@ToolTip8: Resets the LABELMAX= option to its default.
ToolTips.@ToolTip9: Resets the SCALE= option to its default.
ToolTips.@ToolTip10: Resets the TIPMAX= option to its default.
ToolTips.@ToolTip11: Resets the WIDTH= option to its default.

Help.#cdata: Resets the specified option to its default value.

ToolTips.@ToolTip1: Does not scale the components of graph proportionally.
ToolTips.@ToolTip2: Scales the components of graph proportionally.

Help.#cdata: Specifies the width of any graph. Requires a nonnegative number.

ToolTips.@ToolTip1: Turns on the ability to edit ODS graphics output with the ODS Graphics Editor.
ToolTips.@ToolTip2: Turns off the ability to edit ODS graphics output with the ODS Graphics Editor.

Help.#cdata: Determines whether you can edit ODS graphics output with the ODS Graphics Editor. Default: OFF

Specifies the maximum number of distinct mouse-over areas allowed before data tips are disabled. 
Default: 500
Specifies the width of any graph. Requires a nonnegative number.
Enables an option or statement.
Specifies that ODS use traditional SAS/GRAPH option settings for non-graphical output.
Specifies that ODS not use traditional SAS/GRAPH option settings for non-graphical output.

ToolTips.@ToolTip1: Generates a list of bookmarks for your PDF file. The bookmarks are not automatically displayed when  you open the PDF file.
ToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies not to generate a list of bookmarks for your PDF file.
ToolTips.@ToolTip3: Generates a list of bookmarks for your PDF file. The bookmarks are automatically displayed when you  open the PDF file.

Help.#cdata: Specifies whether to generate and display the list of bookmarks for a PDF file.
Specifies to generate bookmarks in the PDF file.
Specifies not to generate bookmarks in the PDF file.

ToolTips.@ToolTip1: Creates full color output for both text and graphics.
ToolTips.@ToolTip2: Creates gray scale output for both text and graphics.
ToolTips.@ToolTip3: Creates monochromatic output for both text and graphics.
ToolTips.@ToolTip4: Does not use all the color information that the style definition provides.
ToolTips.@ToolTip5: Uses all the color information that a style definition provides, including background color.

Help.#cdata: Applies the specified color scheme to your output.
Controls the compression of a PDF file. Compression reduces the size of the file.

Specifies that ODS omit the table of contents (Bookmark list) that is produced by default when 
producing PDF or PDFMARK output.

[Syntax: PACKAGE <package-name>] 
    
Specifies that the output from the destination be added to a package.
Enables ODS to insert special tags into a PostScript file.
Adds notes to a PDF file for items that are associated with the FLYOVER= style attribute.

Modifies the behavior of PDFMARK so that notes are not added to the file for items that are 
associated with the FLYOVER= style attribute.
Controls the level of the expansion of the table of contents in PDF documents.
Inserts into the metadata of a file the text string that you specify as the subject.
For multiple page tables, ensures uniformity from page to page within a single table.

Opens, manages, or closes the RTF destination, which produces measured output that is written in 
Rich Text Format for use with Microsoft Word 2002.
